utterances: But it's…
I'm sorry.
There is…
…a possibility, though, right?
Well, there is one other technology that's - that may actually be more pervasive, quicker than WiMAX, it's called long-term evolution, LTE.
And it's basically the next generation of high-speed cellular service.
It's going to be comparable to WiMAX.
And it actually at this point has more support.
Both AT&T and Verizon are supporting it.
Right.
So, that may actually get a faster and broader distribution than WiMAX does, and may beat WiMAX to the crunch.
And the other thing is that whether it's WiMAX or LTE, it's probably not going to be the way Wi-Fi is, which is essentially free.
It's not like you're going to set up a little WiMAX node on top of your house and share your Internet connection with your neighbor.
This is going to be controlled by the cellular companies as far as the actual access to the signal is concerned.
But because it's open Internet, it means that other people are free to develop applications on it.
Right.
And that's where it gets very interesting - extremely interesting.
I'm sure Google and many other people are anxious to find ways to exploit this technology.
Liza, thanks for the call.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Here is an e-mail from Debbie(ph) in Concord, New Hampshire.
We got a big screen TV with HD and digital phones and high-speed Internet connection for Christmas.
My husband spent most of his waking hours reading each of those manuals with little success.
Why can't the Gizmos be more people-friendly and easier to use for us plain folk over 55 years of age?
Thanks very much.
Larry Magid, is there any robot that's going to come and explain how all these other stuff works?
O'DOWD: And maybe the biggest match yet is blossoming in downtown Mesa, just outside of Phoenix.
In the past year, Mayor Scott Smith has announced plans for five - yes, five - satellite campuses for private liberal arts colleges, all in operation by next year.
We have Westminster College; from Fulton, Missouri.
I sure hope so.
I mean, I remember the days when our TVs had, what, 12 channels and an on-off switch and there were some knobs in the back that you didn't mess with.
And if they needed to be mess with, some guy came and did it.

I think that watching television has become much more complicated than it ever has, not only do you have to figure out your new high-screen TV, you have to figure out your personal video recorder, your various options on your DVD, and then you plug in an Apple TV.
I think that consumers - I don't know if there'll be a backlash, but consumers have a reason to be concerned about the complexity of all this technology.
It's a big issue in my home.
Because, okay, I'm the geek and, you know, I don't mind doing all this.
But one day, my daughter came up to me when she was in high school and said, daddy, I just want to watch television.
And I can't figure out how to do it.
And it's pretty sad.
So I think the industry has a long way to go to make this simple and more seamless.
And Sean, I understand that you tried out a camcorder that, well, gave you advice.
Yeah.
I mean, I think we're starting to see now whether it's in TVs or camcorders or GPS an effort to actually make the devices usable.
And I'm hoping that happens with TVs.
It's happening - camcorders now, both Panasonic and Sony, have models that do face recognition.
They can tell a person is in the frame.
And they'll do things.
They'll make sure that person's in focus.
They'll make sure the lighting and the colors are right on that person.
If that person moves, they'll track that person to keep them looking good.
And then, Panasonic added a feature where it analyzes the video you just shot.
And if it came out badly, it says, you know why this didn't come out, right?
You better reshoot it.
Huh.
And - which is great because normally you have to go home to figure that out.
Figure that out.
Thanks to you both.
And have a good trip home when the show ends tomorrow.
Appreciate your time.
Thanks a lot.
Thank you.
Larry Magid, a tech analyst for CBS News who also writes for the New York Times, and Sean Captain of Popular Science magazine and PopSci.com.
They joined us from the floor of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
Coming up, former Senator George McGovern will be here in Studio 3A.
He's calling for the impeachment of President Bush and Vice President Cheney.
If you'd like to join us, 800-989-8255.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
President Trump's address to Congress last night was a chance to double down on one very big campaign promise.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
Tonight, I am also calling on this Congress to repeal and replace Obamacare.
(APPLAUSE)
We have, of course, been hearing that from Republicans for years.
Now they're driving the train.
And it's up to them to make it happen.
So what's the plan?
NPR health policy correspondent Alison Kodjak is here to suss that out.
Good morning, Alison.
Good morning, Rachel.
So it didn't sound like the president gave any new details about health care last night.
But he did appear to embrace this Republican mantra that people should have access to purchase health care.
You - he used that word, access.
Yeah, he did.
Remind us why that's important.
Well, it's really a step back from some of the promises he had made earlier during the campaign and early in his presidency, that - where he said he wants everyone to have health care.
Access to health care suggests that people have the potential to buy health insurance if they want to.
But it's not required.
It's not required.

And it allows Republicans and the president a little bit of cover if, when their repeal and replace goes through, we find that a lot of people don't have insurance who did under the Affordable Care Act, which is what - at least with the plan that's out there now, that's what a lot of people are expecting.
Did he say anything about what he wants in a replacement?
Well, he made - he gave a list of, what he said, principles that he wants to see.
What was interesting about the list is that it's essentially exactly the same as the list of principles that Speaker Paul Ryan released last week.
There was...
This was the much hailed House plan that everyone's been talking about.
House plan, yeah, that's being sort of looked at by the Congressional Budget Office.
And I'm sure it delighted Speaker Ryan because he basically went along with all those principles, you know...
Preexisting conditions...
...Preexisting conditions, health savings accounts, tax credits, Medicaid, sending it to the states as block grants.
So it was almost as if he was reading off of Speaker Ryan's script rather than giving out his own ideas.
He also mentioned the Food and Drug Administration and that it could use some reform.
He wasn't very specific about that.
Any idea what that means?
Well, let's listen to what he said.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
Megan's story is about the unbounded power of a father's love for a daughter.
But our slow and burdensome approval process at the Food and Drug Administration keeps too many advances, like the one that saved Megan's life, from reaching those in need.
Who's Megan?
